verses.text: Paul, a servant of Jesus Christ, called to be an apostle, set apart for the gospel of God,
verses.comment: Paul introduces himself as an apostle, emphasizing his divine calling and mission. The phrase 'set apart' echoes the biblical idea of being consecrated for a holy task (Gal. 1:15; Jer. 1:5).

verses.text: which He promised beforehand through His prophets in the Holy Scriptures,
verses.comment: The gospel's roots stretch back to Old Testament prophecy (see Isa. 53; Ps. 22), showing unity of Scripture and God’s unfolding salvation plan. Note the special authority of 'Holy Scriptures.'

verses.text: concerning His Son, who was born of the seed of David according to the flesh,
verses.comment: This verse affirms Christ’s true humanity and fulfillment of the Davidic covenant (2 Sam. 7:12). Shows God's promise is realized in Jesus as Messiah, rooted in history and lineage.

verses.text: and was declared to be the Son of God in power according to the Spirit of holiness by His resurrection from the dead—Jesus Christ our Lord.
verses.comment: Paul reveals both Jesus’ divinity and the power of the resurrection (see Acts 2:24-36). The Spirit's role highlights a divine process. 'Our Lord' stresses Jesus' lordship over believers.

verses.text: Through Him we received grace and apostleship to bring about the obedience of faith among all the nations for His name’s sake,
verses.comment: Obedience and faith are inseparable, manifesting true discipleship. The call to all nations underlines universal mission. The grace given signals sacramental life (see Acts 15:11).

verses.text: among whom you also are called to belong to Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: The 'call' is effectual—God’s initiative draws believers into union with Christ. Belonging signals intimate attachment, part of a worldwide community.

verses.text: To all who are in Rome, beloved of God, called to be saints: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: All believers are 'saints,' indicating a calling to holiness. Paul’s greeting balances divine favor (grace) and reconciliation (peace). The double blessing reflects liturgical language.

verses.text: First, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for all of you, because your faith is proclaimed throughout the whole world.
verses.comment: Paul’s thankfulness shows the importance of community faith. Global witness stresses mission and unity in one body of believers, linking prayer with Christ’s mediation.

verses.text: For God is my witness, whom I serve with my spirit in the gospel of His Son, that without ceasing I remember you in my prayers,
verses.comment: Paul’s service is spiritual, not just ceremonial. Prayer for others illustrates the value of intercession and persistence. The apostle’s priestly heart is evident.

verses.text: asking always in my prayers if somehow now at last, by the will of God, I may succeed in coming to you.
verses.comment: Paul’s submission to God’s will models dependence and humility. Desire for gathering with the faithful recalls the value of spiritual fellowship.

verses.text: For I long to see you, so that I may impart to you some spiritual gift to strengthen you—
verses.comment: Paul sees himself as a channel of grace. Spiritual gifts here may suggest an apostolic laying on of hands or spiritual encouragement (see 1 Tim. 4:14), hinting at sacramental means.

verses.text: that is, that we may be encouraged together by each other’s faith, both yours and mine.
verses.comment: Mutual encouragement in faith builds unity—fellowship is both personal and corporate, foundational to life in Christ.

verses.text: I do not want you to be unaware, brothers, that I have often planned to come to you (but was prevented until now), so that I might have some harvest among you just as among the other Gentiles.
verses.comment: Paul’s evangelistic zeal aims for spiritual fruit—conversion and growth. The mention of 'brothers' signals shared spiritual kinship.

verses.text: I am under obligation both to Greeks and to barbarians, both to the wise and to the foolish.
verses.comment: The gospel’s reach is all-inclusive, breaking barriers of culture and intellect. The sense of obligation reflects apostolic responsibility and mission.

verses.text: So I am eager to preach the gospel to you also who are in Rome.
verses.comment: Paul’s enduring desire for sharing the good news demonstrates the central role of the gospel in apostolic ministry.

verses.text: For I am not ashamed of the gospel, for it is the power of God for salvation to everyone who believes, to the Jew first and also to the Greek.
verses.comment: Salvation in Christ is power—divine grace working through human belief. The order 'Jew first' reflects redemptive history’s priority and inclusion of all peoples.

verses.text: For in it the righteousness of God is revealed from faith to faith, just as it is written, 'The righteous shall live by faith.'
verses.comment: 'Faith to faith' suggests growth and continuity in spiritual life. God’s righteousness is both a gift and a call; justification leads to sanctification.

verses.text: For the wrath of God is being revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men, who by unrighteousness suppress the truth.
verses.comment: Divine justice actively opposes sin. Suppressing truth is a conscious moral act, prompting God’s judgment—showing the need for divine mercy.

verses.text: For what can be known about God is plain to them, because God has shown it to them.
verses.comment: Even apart from revelation, creation points to God. Humanity is accountable by being granted knowledge—natural law and conscience.

verses.text: For His invisible attributes, namely, His eternal power and divine nature, have been clearly seen since the creation of the world, being understood through the things that have been made. So they are without excuse.
verses.comment: Natural revelation reveals God’s existence and character. The lack of 'excuse' stresses moral responsibility and the clarity of creation as testimony.

verses.text: For although they knew God, they did not honor Him as God or give thanks, but they became futile in their thinking, and their foolish hearts were darkened.
verses.comment: Failure to worship and thank leads to spiritual blindness. Gratitude is central to true worship, the doorway to light and understanding.

verses.text: Claiming to be wise, they became fools,
verses.comment: Human wisdom apart from God leads to folly. Spiritual discernment is found only in humble faith.

verses.text: and exchanged the glory of the immortal God for images resembling mortal man and birds and animals and creeping things.
verses.comment: Idolatry replaces God with created things. The descent into various forms shows corruption of worship—an affront to God’s unique glory.

verses.text: Therefore God gave them over in the desires of their hearts to impurity, so that their bodies were dishonored among themselves.
verses.comment: Rejecting God results in the surrender to one’s own destructive choices. The bodily dimension underscores the importance of purity and embodied holiness.

verses.text: They exchanged the truth about God for a lie, and worshiped and served created things rather than the Creator, who is forever praised. Amen.
verses.comment: Worship must be directed only to God. Created things are not worthy, highlighting the danger of distorted veneration.

verses.text: For this reason God gave them up to shameful passions. Their women exchanged natural relations for those that are against nature;
verses.comment: Sin distorts natural order. Paul’s description of passions against nature reflects rejection of divine design for humanity.

verses.text: and likewise the men gave up natural relations with women and were consumed with lust for one another, men committing shameful acts with men and receiving in themselves the due penalty for their error.
verses.comment: Paul sees sexual immorality as both cause and result of turning from God. The penalty is spiritual and physical consequence.

verses.text: And since they did not see fit to acknowledge God, God gave them up to a debased mind to do what ought not to be done.
verses.comment: Persistent rejection of truth leads to distorted thinking. The giving over shows God’s respect for freedom but also judgment.

verses.text: They were filled with all unrighteousness, evil, greed, and malice. They are full of envy, murder, strife, deceit, and malice. They are gossipers,
verses.comment: Sin’s power corrupts both actions and speech, unraveling community and personal virtue.

verses.text: slanderers, God-haters, insolent, arrogant, and boastful; inventors of evil, disobedient to parents,
verses.comment: Moral collapse affects families and relationships. Disobedience to parents violates commandment, undermining society’s foundation.

verses.text: foolish, faithless, heartless, ruthless.
verses.comment: Heart and mind become hardened by sin. Lack of fidelity and compassion marks spiritual emptiness.

verses.text: Though they know God’s righteous decree that those who practice such things deserve death, they not only continue to do them but also approve of those who practice them.
verses.comment: Willful embrace of sin leads to spiritual death. Condoning evil deepens separation, showing urgent need for grace and transformation.
